Title: Periods of American Literature (the basics)
References: ABRAMS, M. H. 1985. A Glossary of Literary Terms. 7th ed. Boston : Hartcourt Brace Jovanovich College Publishers, 1985. 366 p.
Content:
1. Native American Period - (arrived 40,000 - 20,000 BC) 

  •  also known as American Indian literature
  • characteristics: oral literature, creating myths, deep respect for anvironment and animals, using stories to teach moral lessons and to teach practical information about to world.

2. Puritanism - (1600 - 1800 AD)

  • highlights: the first American colonies are established, also the period of Salem Witch Trials
  • characteristics:use of plain style of writing, wrote mostly diaries and histories expressing connections with God and everyday life, saw religion as their own personal experience, people believed in "original sin" and elected who will be saved
  • famous authors: William Bradford (Of Plymounth Plantation), Edward Taylor (Huswifery), Jonathan Edwards (Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God)

3. Rationalism - (1750 - 1800)

  • also known as The Enlightenment period
  • highlights: Revolutionary war, the creation of the Constitution, the Bill of Rights and the Declaration of Independence
  • characteristics: humans can arrive at truth not by relying on the authority or on religious faith but by using deductive reasoning, most writers are philosophers or scientists writting speeches or pamphlets
  • famous authors: Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Paine (The Crisis), Phyllis Wheatley

4. Romanticism - (1800 - 1860)

  • highlights: the War of 1812, California gold rush, industrialization
  • characteristics:used dark and supernatural themes/settings (Gothic style), saw poetry as the highest expression of the imagination, placed faith in inner experience and the power of imagination
  • famous authors:Emily Dickinson, Edgar Allan Poe (The Raven), Washington Irving (Rip Van Winkle)

5. Transcendentalism - (1840 - 1860)

  • also known as The American Renaissance
  • highlights:abolitionism, women's suffrage movements,
  • characteristics:humans and everything in the world is the reflection of the Divine Soul, people can use their intuition to behold God's spirit revealed in nature or in their own Soul
  • famous authors:Henry David Thoreau (Life in the Woods), Louisa May Alcott (Little Women)

6. Realism - (1865 - 1900)

  • highlights:the impact of the Civil War, the Reconstruction,
  • characteristics:authors wanted to explain psychological/social behavior, feelings of disillusionment, poor factory workers, corrupt politicians, factories replacing farmlands
  • famous authors:Mark Twain (The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn), Jack London (Call of the Wild), Stephen Crane (The Open Boat)

7. Naturalism - (1900 - 1914)

  • a harsher form of realism
  • characteristics:authors use the Darwins theory of determinism,
  • famous authors:Jack London (The Law of Life), Frank Norris, Theodore Dreiser

8. Modernism - (1914 - 1939)

  • also called the Jazz Age or the Harlem Renaissance
  • highlights:the Great War, era between two wars, economic depression,
  • characteristics: authors wrote about the influence of the Great War, era of the Roaring Twenties, themes connected with the Great economic depression
  • famous authors (PROSE):Gertrude Stein, Francis Scott Fitzgerald (The Great Gatsby), William Faulkner (A Rose for Emily), Ernest Hemingway (For Whom the Bell Tolls), John Steinbeck (Of Mice and Men)
  • famous authors (POETRY):Robert Lee Frost (Acquainted with the Night), William Carlos Williams, Thomas Stearns Eliot (The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock), Ezra Pound

9. Contemporary period - (1939 - present)

9.1. Literature of the 40s

  • characteristics: authors made use of their wartime experiences during the World War II., the war had elicited the strongest fiction in the forties
  • famous authors:Norman Mailer (The Naked and the Dead), James Jones

9.2. Literature of the 50s

  •  characteristics: anti-traditional literary movements, period of cultural conformity
  • famous authors:The Beat Writers (Allen Ginsberg, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Jack Kerouac and William Burroughs), The Black Mountain Poets (Charles Olson, Robert Creeley), New York Poets (Frank O'Hara, Kenneth Koch) Vladimír Nabokov, Henry Miller

9.3. Literature of the 60s - 90s

  • also called Postmodernism (it manifested itself as an assault upon traditional definitions of narrative, it is a mixture of various forms)
  • highlights:The War in Korea, The War in Vietnam
  • characteristics: rebellious young movement, opposition to the war 
  • famous authors (POETRY):Elisabeth Bishop, Sylvia Plath, Robert Lowell, Adriene Rich
  • famous authors (PROSE):James Baldwin, Alice Walker, Truman Capote, Philip Roth, John Bart - and many more
